captions.text:
While many search for the proverbial
fountain of youth, you might be wondering

why do we age in the first place?
What is it about our bodies or cells

biologically that causes us to grow old?
There is a variety of internal and

external factors such as diet, exercise
or environmental stress which all

contribute to cell damage and repair and
effect the rate of aging,  But the
surprising truth is that apart from these, we actually have a biological

clock buried within our genetic makeup.
And this clock can only run for so long,
in other words we are programmed to die. Your body is made up of trillions of cells

which are constantly going through cell
division and every time they divide they

make a copy of their DNA as well.  This
DNA is tightly packed into structures
called chromosomes
of which humans have twenty three pairs.  The problem is, DNA replication isn't

quite perfect and skips over the end of
each chromosome.

To protect against important DNA
information being cut out we have

something called telomeres on the
end of chromosomes which are essentially
meaningless repeats of DNA that we can afford to lose.  But everytime

our cells divide these telomeres become
shorter and shorter until eventually

they've been entirely stripped away.  At
which point the cell no longer divides.

Some flat worms are able to endlessly
regenerate their telomeres making them

effectively biologically immortal, but
their lifespans do vary and they're

still susceptible to disease further
suggesting that aging is a mix of
genetic and environmental factors.

But why don't our cells do this?
Ultimately this replication limit

actually helps to prevent cancer which
is the uncontrollable growth of cells

and evasion of cell death.  The point at
which a cell stops replicating is
known as cellular senescence.

In humans this replication limit is around
fifty times.  Once it is reached the cell

gradually begins to lose its function
and die causing age-related

characteristics.  This also helps to
explain why life expectancy is a

strongly heritable trait from your
parents, because you got your initial
telomere length from them.

Got a burning question you want answered?
Ask it in the comments, or on facebook and twitter,

and subscribe for more weekly science
videos.

comments.text:
“Human life must be some kind of mistake. The truth of this will be 
sufficiently obvious if we only remember that man is a compound of needs 
and necessities hard to satisfy; and that even when they are satisfied, all 
he obtains is a state of painlessness, where nothing remains to him but 
abandonment to boredom. This is direct proof that existence has no
real value in itself; for what is boredom but the feeling of the emptiness 
of life? If life—the craving for which is the very essence of our 
being—were possessed of any positive intrinsic value, there would be no 
such thing as boredom at all: mere existence would satisfy us in itself, 
and we should want for nothing.”

― Arthur Schopenhauer, Studies in Pessimism: The Essays﻿

comments.author: P3ndu1uM

comments.text:
The blue color of the sky is due to Rayleigh scattering As light moves 
through the atmosphere, most of the longer wavelengths pass straight 
through. Little of the red, orange and yellow light is affected by the air.

However, much of the shorter wavelength light is absorbed by the gas 
molecules. The absorbed blue light is then radiated in different 
directions. It gets scattered all around the sky. Whichever direction you 
look, some of this scattered blue light reaches you. Since you see the blue 
light from everywhere overhead, the sky looks blue.

As you look closer to the horizon, the sky appears much paler in color. To 
reach you, the scattered blue light must pass through more air. Some of it 
gets scattered away again in other directions. Less blue light reaches your 
eyes. The color of the sky near the horizon appears paler or white.

comments.text:
A smile can be traced back 30 million years to a fear grin. Monkeys and 
apes used this to show predators that they were harmless and the predator 
would become more friendly. Humans adopted this as a sign of happiness but 
a smile can also be used when scared and intimated to show you're not 
afraid of the threat and denying the danger. So next time you watch a 
horror movie or someone tries to intimate, you smile

estimated that eventually people will be able to live to 150 and maybe 
beyond. Yes, that is said quite often that any cure would only be available 
to the rich. As for over population, scientists say this could be overcome 
(don't know how though!) . I do still think though that aging can be cured, 
its just my opinion, I even held that opinion as a small child. As I 
mentioned in one of my previous posts, aging does not happen by magic 
(there's a reason for it), if it did, I would say yes, it cannot be cured. 
As it stands, there is a reason it happens, so therefore I believe it can 
be stopped or controlled.

I have my opinion though and I respect yours. I must go, been interesting 
chatting and perhaps chat to you again.
comments.author: Paul J

comments.text:
+Paul J I think the most we can do is increase out life expectancy. Besides 
finding a cure for aging will cause a huge disaster on Earth, with the 
death rate drastically dropping. Natural resources will run out in no time 
(this is if the cure was in mass production and available for everyone) and 
the over population will force people to start populating other planets 
(Mars).
But if we think logically, a cure will only be available to the high class 
and rich citizens of western countries and only powerful people from the 
rest of the world. It won't make a difference. And say even if the cure was 
being considered to be mass-produced, economists will strongly be against 
it because of the reasons I mentioned earlier.

No matter what way you look at it, its a lose-lose situation. Immortality 
isn't a cheap wish.
comments.author: Random Videos Again

comments.text:
+Random Videos Again Whether the whole thing with mice has any effect of 
humans or not does not matter because if they don't cure aging in humans 
that way, they will do it another way. You simply cannot tell me aging is 
unavoidable. You don't know that for certain. I personally DO think it is 
avoidable and so do many others. There are already scientists who say they 
know what aging is, so that is a good start to be able to cure it.

And no, im not afraid of death, if I die, I die, but I just think there 
will be a cure for aging eventually. They are making new discoveries about 
the aging process all the time. Imagine the discoveries they will be able 
to make in 60 or 70 years when technology is a lot more advanced. Curing 
aging just takes a better understanding of the human body than we have at 
the moment and in the future, there will be more technology to understand 
the body better.
comments.author: Paul J

comments.text:
+Paul J Well, I just read about it and let me tell you, it will have no 
effect on mankind. They just simply put the blood of young mice into older 
mice and voila ._. Humans donate blood all the time and they stated it will 
probably serve no benefit to humans. So no, aging is something that is 
unavoidable.

No offense but I think that telling yourself a cure for aging will be found 
is just a fancy way of telling others you're afraid of death. If life was a 
contract, death was always a condition for receiving the privilege of 
living and thinking. I just want to live my life in such a way that in my 
death bed I'll say to myself "I've had enough of life, I think its time I 
see what really is on the other side". 

http://www.bostonglobe.com/news/science/2014/05/04/blood-from-young-mice-reverses-aging-brain-muscles/iepDMMf7wrLJy6WgXqpdIJ/story.html
comments.author: Random Videos Again

immune to aging.﻿
